back.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: in, into, or to the place or position where someone or something was before
back.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: I’ll be back in a minute.
Put that book back where you found it!
He was back home by half past eleven.
It’s possible to travel there and back in a day.
Rory plugged the cable back into the socket.
I feel like going back to bed.
We ought to try and get back before it gets dark.
back.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: You go back to a place
It’s time to go back home
back.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: in or into the condition or situation you were in before
back.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Gary woke at 4 am and couldn’t get back to sleep.
It took me a long time to get my confidence back.
If you decide to marry him, there will be no going back (=you will not be able to get back to your previous situation).
There’s no way I’m going back to being poor.
It’ll take a while for things to get back to normal.
back.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: in or to a place where you lived or worked before
back.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: It reminded me of evenings back home.
She was the one who had fired him from his first job back in South Africa.
back.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: in the opposite direction from the way you are facing
back.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: He glanced back at the house.
She tilted her head back to look at him.
back.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: if you do something back, you do it as a reply or reaction to what someone has said or done
back.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Can I call you back later?
I’ll pay you back on Friday.
If he hits you, you just hit him back.
back.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: if you give something, get something etc back, you return it to the person who first had it, or you have it returned to you
back.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Can we have our ball back, please?
I want all my books back as soon as you’ve finished with them.
Give me back that letter! It’s none of your business!
back.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: in or towards a time in the past
back.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: a pile of newspapers dating back to the 1970s
A lot of emotional problems can be traced back to childhood.
Looking back on it, I should have known he was unhappy.
At times, I think back to my life in Moscow.
His wife died a couple of years back.
He called me a while back.
The house was built back in 1235.
back.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: Go back over your work to check for any mistakes.
Liverpool were back level again two minutes later with a superb goal.
back.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: away from a surface, person, or thing
back.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: She pulled the bandage back very carefully.
Her hair was brushed back from her face.
The woman nodded and stood back, allowing Patrick to enter.
back.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: towards the beginning of a book, film, or computer document etc
back.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: Turn back to the summaries at the end of section 1.5.
Clicking on the icon will take you back to the previous web page.
Wind the tape back to the beginning.
back.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: the part of the body between the neck and legs, on the opposite side to the stomach and chest
back.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: The cat arched its back and hissed.
My feet were sore and my back was aching.
Keep your head up and your back straight.
To avoid back problems, always bend your knees when you lift heavy objects.
He lay on his back and gazed at the ceiling.
Johnny was lying flat on his back in the middle of the floor.
Anna stood with her back to the window.
The girl appeared again, now with a little baby on her back.
back.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: the bones between your neck and the top of your legs
back.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: He broke his back in a motorbike accident.
back.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: the part of something that is furthest from the front
back.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: a T-shirt with a picture of a snake on the back
Kids should always wear seat belts, even in back.
Tom’s working on the car out back.
Have you looked round the back?
He kissed her on the back of her head.
Her window faced the backs of the houses.
Two men were sitting in the back of the car.
a small shop with an office at the back
back.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: the less important side or surface of something such as a piece of paper or card
back.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: Paul scribbled his address on the back of an envelope.
The credits are listed on the back of the album.
back.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: the part of a seat that you lean against when you are sitting
back.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: He rested his arm on the back of the sofa.
back.translation[1].definitions[5].defin: the last pages of a book or newspaper
back.translation[1].definitions[5].examp: The sports pages are usually at the back.
The answers are in the back of the book.
back.translation[1].definitions[6].defin: a defending player in a sports team
back.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to support someone or something, especially by giving them money or using your influence
back.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: The scheme has been backed by several major companies in the region.
Some suspected that the rebellion was backed and financed by the US.
back.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to support an idea by providing facts, proof etc
back.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: His claims are not backed by any scientific evidence.
back.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: to move backwards, or make someone or something move backwards
back.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: She backed into a doorway to let the crowds pass by.
He began to back her towards the open door.
back somebody into/towards/out of etc something
I backed the car into the garage.
back something into/towards/out of etc something
back.translation[2].definitions[3].defin: to put a material or substance onto the back of something, in order to protect it or make it stronger
back.translation[2].definitions[3].examp: The photograph is backed with cardboard.
back.translation[2].definitions[3].note_: Back is usually passive in this meaning
back.translation[2].definitions[4].defin: to be at the back of something or behind it
back.translation[2].definitions[4].examp: The Jandia Peninsula is a stretch of white sands backed by a mountain range.
back.translation[2].definitions[4].note_: Back is usually passive in this meaning
back.translation[2].definitions[5].defin: to play or sing the music that supports the main singer or musician
back.translation[2].definitions[5].examp: They performed all their hits, backed by a 40-piece orchestra.
back.translation[2].definitions[5].note_: Back is usually passive in this meaning
back.translation[2].definitions[6].defin: to risk money on whether a particular horse, dog, team etc wins something
back.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: at or in the back of something
back.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: You’ll be sleeping in the back bedroom.
I keep my keys in my back pocket.
There was the sound of giggling from the back row.
The rabbit had one of its back legs caught in a trap.
back.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: We left by the back gate.
back.translation[3].definitions[2].examp: The back view of the hotel was even less appealing than the front.
back.translation[3].definitions[3].defin: a back vowel sound is made by lifting your tongue at the back of your mouth
back.translation[4].definitions[0].defin: to support someone or something, especially by giving money or using your influence
back.translation[4].definitions[0].examp: The board backed Mr Standley, who plans to cut costs.
Shareholders have backed a plan to build a second plant.
back.translation[4].definitions[1].defin: if SECURITIES are backed by particular assets, they are supported by income from them
back.translation[4].definitions[1].examp: This new generation of securities is backed by aircraft leases, royalty streams from films, student loans and auto loans.
